caption: Nice and peaceful view. The Cafe was quite busy at lunch time, but nice servers. I got halzenut coffee. The coffee was OK since I'm used to stronger taste. It might be of excellent taste for those who prefer a lighter taste.

This delightful bookshop and caf√© is an ideal place to visit before catching the funicular to the Sacr√©-C≈ìur Basilica, located just a short stroll from the top of Montmartre.  The collection of distinctive art books is fascinating and definitely worth exploring. Although I didn‚Äôt try the caf√© myself, it appears to be a lovely spot to unwind. Overall, it offers a charming atmosphere that‚Äôs well worth experiencing!
Really unique and beautiful space. It has a great selection of books ranging from all topics. Lots of nice postcards and art books as well. There is a cafe and a gallery space inside.

A great vibe and a good place to spend some time on a rainy or overcast day. Saw an unexpected and delightful exhibit by Gilbert Peyre, with a guide who took his time to animate each of the pieces of art as we walked through, giving a description and encouraging thoughts from the crowd. Art, books, coffee and a great space all under one roof

I came here from Tiktok :) and since it's super close to the Basilica I decided I should visit to have a look at the bookstore.  The decorations were nice but nothing too special. If you just want to check something off in Montmarte area or if you're looking for a good cafe, this might be the one. I saw many enjoying their food and drinks (and also work) here

The exhibition was quite impressive; however, I couldn't fully appreciate it due to the rude behavior of the staff at the reception. One employee even shouted at me, and their attitude felt discriminatory and homophobic. Additionally, after I finished my coffee, the bar staff asked me to leave to accommodate other guests, which I found completely unacceptable. It‚Äôs disappointing that these experiences prevented me from enjoying the art.

The library and cafe - and exhibition space - in my view is hyped up thanks to Instagram. Visitors to the library note that they stock only French language books - but a good collection. The coffee shop was below average - both the coffee and the serving staff (not welcoming). We bought 20‚Ç¨ tickets to see the ongoing exhibition upstairs - hugely disappointing for that price.

Cute bookshop and cafe to visit before mounting to the Sacre-Coeur Basilica with funiculare (cause it‚Äôs just a bit ahead of the butte Montmartre).  They offer a selection of niche art books, interesting to look. Also, they have a cafe that I haven‚Äôt tried but I think it‚Äôs better to check out the books and the atmosphere and then drinking coffee elsewhere. Anyways it‚Äôs a cool aesthetic place.
Very interesting and exotic museum in the busy area of Montmartre. Two floors with different exhibit, and a restaurant. Approximately 1 or 2 hours of visit.

Beautiful exhibit space with food and drink options. The artist was there helping with the exhibit so it was fun meeting him as well. The door to the toilet and cost room is very tricky, but eventually I figured it out. For my family definitely a better visit than the sacre coeur.

Factory turned into unconventional museum, with interesting exhibition of La Fabuloserie, collection of non-traditional art pieces created by self-taught artists all over the world üåèü™úüé≠Battalion suggestion: provide more English narratives ‚Ä¶

I haven't visited their exhibition yet but it's a cozy space with an artful coffee shop and bookstore in a beautiful glass building.  I will come back to try their cafe because I really like the atmosphere there.

Such an interesting and warm space! A good option where you can spend a calm day inside, just looking at the endless shelves of beautiful books. The cafe is a little overpriced, otherwise great place.

It's an old factory hall with a coffee shop, gallery, and art shop inside. Also there was an exhibition when we visited.  Great place if you look for special or unusual things that you cannot find on Amazon. Also a lot of R rated art stuff.. Coffee was average.  Well worth a visit.

Exhibition hall, bookstore and cafe. The exhibition I saw was of a pretty high quality despite their budget is a fraction of the usual goto places. Definitely a good destination if you want to go off track. Th√© caf√© was very average and the bookstore nice but not outstanding.
Very nice library and coffee place in an authentically parisian placd

Fascinating exhibitions featuring artists with various backgrounds and styles. The bookshop is worth a visit (even without visiting the exhibition!). The staff are welcoming and knowledgeable, offering further insight into the content and curation. Feels authentic amidst the tourist spots surrounding the Sacre Coeur.
Lovely gallery with really interesting artwork for the 'Hey!' exhibition. You need to pay to get in but the ticket lets you in to the upstairs and downstairs areas.

A different side of Paris from the one on display.  Artists of the people it looked like, worth seeing.  Funny how people stand in line for 45 min to see the old church and don't seem to understand religion.  No wait here, with the secular world on display.
Interesting museum of outsider art.

A hidden gem among many art museums in Paris. Very suitable property for exhibitions. Their outsider art can be demanding (even brute), but do visit, if you like avant-garde and pop art paintings and graphics. The video presentation of Laurie Lipton is interesting, for example. The entrance fee was 9 euros. The caf√© and the museum shop are also worth a visit. But on the other hand, the arrangements can also be a little bit free. It can happen that the opening time is not precisely the promised. Or the book shop is not open because the worker has not arrived.
Didn‚Äôt go to the exhibition as don‚Äôt feel like it. Quiet place close to Sacre coeur
Expected a more friendly staff. Space is awesome of course and very glad we have an art brut dedicated place in Paris. They have a good restaurant and library too.

I've wanted to stop at this museum for the last few years and very glad that I finally went. At the foot of Montmartre and Sacre Coure with some of the best contemporary art I've seen in a long time. 9 euro for tickets, bags go to a locker, so bring a euro to lock the bags.The euro is returned with the key. Good coffee and pastries too.

Great art gallery with a little cafe and bookstore! It‚Äôs close to some tourist attractions but is not busy inside. To see the art exhibit it was around ‚Ç¨7 and was worth the price! The curation of the current exhibit definitely sticks to many signature styles, line art and fine detail taking the spot light. I would‚Äôve liked to see a bit more explanation on the emotional and story aspect of the exhibit itself as much of it felt more focused on a certain aesthetic rather than theme. I enjoyed it overall though and would recommend!
Super vibey tho I think the ticket is a bit expensive ‚Ç¨9 so i didnt actually look at the exhibit. Cafe is very cute
It‚Äôs a great a museum with many hidden treasures.

Halle Saint-Pierre is a charming cultural space in Montmartre, showcasing contemporary art with a focus on outsider and self-taught artists. The gallery's exhibitions are often unusual and thought-provoking, providing a unique perspective on modern creativity. The building itself has a lovely historic feel, and the location near the Sacr√©-C≈ìur adds to its appeal. If you're interested in discovering unconventional art in a welcoming setting, Halle Saint-Pierre is a hidden gem in Paris that‚Äôs definitely worth a visit.
This was a fun way to spend some time. Unusual art that sparks a lot of imagination. The building is itself very unique as well.
Interesting gallery. Mostly US based artists. Nice cafe and book shop. A bit overpriced maybe as entrance costs the same as the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrangerie.
Great little gallery. Spent three hours there looking at some fantastic brut art. Also has a lovely  coffee shop  with Nice coffee and lovely tasty cakes
No goodÔºåno access to the staircase and 2nd platform without ticket
Favorite museum in the word. A lot of na√Øf art and interesting subjects. I always go back. It‚Äôs not too crowded.

The staff racist me. He said if I go to bathroomÔºåI have to buy ticket and another staff lock the door. But when I go to reception to payÔºåthe cashier said the bathroom is just downstairs.  Omg, so mean!

Located just a short walk from the iconic Sacr√©-C≈ìur in the heart of Montmartre, this museum is dedicated to outsider art and features an ever-changing array of fascinating and unconventional exhibits.  Besides the exhibits which are located upstairs, there is also a bookshop and a cafe downstairs.  The bookshop has a ton of unique art books and curiosities, perfect for finding a special souvenir.  And the caf√© is a great spot to relax and enjoy a delicious coffee after visiting the bookshop and checking out the current art exhibit upstairs.

Fantastic museum for naive art. This is where I saw the best exhibition I have ever seen, Art Brut Japonais (Outsider Art) in 2010, absolutely fantastic and very moving. (2nd edition in 2018 that I unfortunately didn‚Äôt see). The caf√© is also good and relatively inexpensive.

Visited the cafe and book shop here. We got two caf√© cr√©me for only 5.40 and we were very pleased with it! Really cool and relaxed atmosphere, a good place to unwind. It felt very welcoming and open.
What a cool place! Check it out!
